newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: CRICKET-NZ OFF TO STRONG START VS ENGLAND AT LUNCH.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-NZ OFF TO STRONG START VS ENGLAND AT LUNCH.

text.p: New Zealand were off to a strong start against England on the first day day of the first test on Friday after being put into bat by the tourists.
On a pitch which promised assistance for the England seam bowlers, openers Bryan Young and Blair Pocock got through to 37 and 25 respectively by the break.
They were helped by some wayward bowling from England's fast-medium quartet, who were guilty of wasting the encouraging pitch conditions.
Only occasionally were the batsmen drawn into a false stroke and with England captain Mike Atherton setting attacking fields, there were some easy runs on offer once the ball beat the inner field.
Left armer Alan Mullally had one strong leg before wicket appeal against Pocock turned down in the second over of the day.
Young had a close shave when he got an inside edge to a ball from fast-medium Darren Gough and it flew past the wickets to the fine leg fence.
The closest England came to a wicket was three minutes before the lunch break when Pocock would have been run out by metres had a throw from Craig White at point hit the wickets.
Pocock, playing his first test since facing England at Lord's in 1994, was called through for a short single and White moved quickly to gather and throw.

The 50 partnership came up in 117 balls and at lunch New Zealand were on track for their first century opening stand in a test since last January, when Craig Spearman and Roger Twose put on 214 on the same ground against Zimbabwe.
The pick of a poor England attack was fast-medium Dominic Cork, but it was a session the tourists would want to forget.
The added worry for England was wicketkeeper Alec Stewart, who required attention after injuring a finger in his left hand early in the session.
